title: Fall of Israel
shortSummary: 2 Kings 17 recounts the downfall of the northern kingdom of Israel due to persistent idolatry and disobedience to God. The chapter details the reign of Hoshea, the Assyrian siege and exile of Israel, and the subsequent resettlement by foreign peoples who adopt syncretistic worship practices. This chapter highlights the consequences of covenant unfaithfulness and God's righteous judgment.
timeline: c. 732-722 BC - Reign of Hoshea and Assyrian exile of Israel

keyCharacters.name: Hoshea
keyCharacters.description: The last king of Israel who reigned for nine years and whose conspiracy against Assyria led to Israel’s downfall.

keyCharacters.name: Shalmaneser
keyCharacters.description: King of Assyria who besieged Samaria and carried Israel into exile.

keyCharacters.name: Jeroboam son of Nebat
keyCharacters.description: The first king of the northern kingdom of Israel whose sins set the pattern of idolatry followed by his successors.

keyCharacters.name: Priests from Israel
keyCharacters.description: Israelite priests brought back by the Assyrian king to teach the new settlers the worship of the God of the land.

definitions.definition: Elevated sites used for worship, often associated with idolatry and pagan rituals contrary to God’s commands.
Sacred trees or wooden idols used in pagan worship, forbidden by the Mosaic Law.
A biblical term referring to the celestial bodies or heavenly beings, often worshiped idolatrously.
Secret plotting or rebellion, here referring to Hoshea’s alliance with Egypt against Assyria.

outline.heading: Hoshea’s Reign and Assyrian Siege
outline.description: Hoshea becomes king of Israel, serves Assyria but conspires with Egypt, leading to his imprisonment. Assyria besieges Samaria for three years and captures it, exiling Israel.

outline.heading: Israel’s Sin and God’s Judgment
outline.description: The chapter explains Israel’s persistent idolatry and covenant disobedience as the cause of their exile, emphasizing their rejection of God’s laws and prophets.

outline.heading: Resettlement and Syncretism
outline.description: Assyria resettles foreign peoples in Samaria who fear the LORD but also worship their own gods, resulting in syncretistic religious practices that persist to the present.

application: Recognize the seriousness of covenant unfaithfulness and idolatry, and strive to remain obedient to God’s commands.
Trust in God’s sovereignty even in times of judgment, knowing He disciplines His people for their good and calls them to repentance.
Guard against syncretism by worshiping God alone and rejecting any form of compromise with false religions.
Learn from Israel’s history to avoid repeating their mistakes in personal faith and community life.

keyVerses.text: In the ninth year of Hoshea the king of Assyria took Samaria, and carried Israel away into Assyria, and placed them in Halah and in Habor by the river of Gozan, and in the cities of the Medes.
keyVerses.significance: This verse marks the historic exile of Israel, fulfilling God’s judgment for their persistent sin.

keyVerses.text: Yet the LORD testified against Israel, and against Judah, by all the prophets, and by all the seers, saying, Turn ye from your evil ways, and keep my commandments and my statutes, according to all the law which I commanded your fathers, and which I sent to you by my servants the prophets.
keyVerses.significance: God’s patient warnings through prophets highlight His desire for repentance despite Israel’s rebellion.

keyVerses.text: So these nations feared the LORD, and served their graven images, both their children, and their children's children: as did their fathers, so do they unto this day.
keyVerses.significance: This verse illustrates the ongoing problem of syncretism and disobedience even after exile.
